ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: working with 16mm film, using blackmagic6k cameras, editing with davinci, script analysis
I learned about the technical aspects of a camera, how to work with a team on mutiple types of film projects, and how to navigate life in a foreign city all the while.
I learned more about film production and practical knowledge for filmmaking. Additionally, I learned the importance of clarity in storytelling.
I learned how to edit sound, video, color, etc in Davinci Resolve, how to use film and digital cameras, and how to execute filmmaking from pre-production through post-production.

I learned a lot of technical filmmaking skills, including: camerawork, editing (analog and digital), sound design, and color-grading. I was able to try directing (and maybe think it's not really for me, but that's useful information).
Introduction to basic filmmaking techniques.
I learned about almost everything to do with film! Camera work, directing, sound, editing, everything!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: very hands-on, you get to experiment with different forms of filmmaking (analog vs. digital), film festival allows you to get inspiration from modern cinema
weaknesses: limited time to work on each project (especially first two) so you don't get to do your best work,

This course was all in all so wonderful. I absolutely loved the projects and the lectures by different experts in the film industry. I would have loved to have watched more films as a group and talked about them with the class.

I think this course provided me with a very strong technical skillset for creating films and an ability to defend creative choices in my films. I feel like some more lectures on the writing process would be helpful and fun.

The greatest strength of the course is the intensive skill-learning. I came into the program knowing that writing is what I'm most interested in, and there wasn't a huge focus on really high-quality writing (and the predetermined group set-up would have been more effective, I think, if it were determined that there was a singular writer, a singular director, etc.). This made it all the more clear to me that writing is what I really love. I think this specific (and maybe pre-set) breakdown of roles could be useful in terms of embracing each individual voice instead of trying to do everything with eight hands.
All the topics we covered were very in-depth, but I would love some more focus on the writing aspect of film!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are new to filmmaking, this is a great introduction. If you already have some experience, it might be too much of a beginner class, yet you still gain great practice.
Yes, absolutely! If you can take this class you should totally do it. It is so fun and all the students are so passionate. Amazing city and people!
Yes, I think it is a wonderful opportunity to become part of the film community at Yale and is especially great for beginners.
Yes, it was incredible learning from a series of different professionals and having several finished products.

It depends what the student is looking for in a summer program. The program is great for people who are very serious about filmmaking, but if the student is really focused on living where their study abroad is, this might not be the program for them, as there is a lot of time in the classroom.
I would! The coursework was great but the experience overall was life-changing!

comments: Neutral
Agree

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: I will consider all the feedback given by my mentors in my future films.
I am excited to do more film at Yale and use my ability to work with others and take on challenges of working in other countries when I graduate.
I'm going to start making my own films and think more critically about choice and structure in films.
I will carry the filmmaking techniques I learned in this program to every future project I am involved in.
I am majoring in film, so I will definitely use everything that I learned in my future career!
